title: 18 most 2018 things happened
story: NewsThe  most  things that have happened in politics this yearIts hard to believe all this really happened during the last yearShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC News"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Its been quite a year for politics. From blimps to budgets, reshuffles to revolts. There have been more crunch weeks for Theresa May than we care to count, while Jeremy Corbyn went from hosting his own music festival to battling Labours anti-Semitism scandal. And through it all Brexit loomed like an ever present spectre. But away from that elusive deal, there has been a whole host of unusual political occurrences to distract us. In fact you might be surprised that all of this really did happen just in the last  months. How much do you remember  . Chris Grayling becomes Tory Party chairman - for all of  seconds  Theresa Mays Cabinet reshuffle descended into chaos when a reported move for Tory Transport Secretary Chris Grayling was announced, then deleted. The Partys official Twitter account reported that Grayling was to be made Conservative Party Chairman. But seconds later the tweet was deleted. Immigration Minister Brandon Lewis later arrived at Downing Street, reportedly to be told he was to be made chairman instead. That left Mr Grayling as Transport Secretary - a post were probably all relieved he stayed in. . Boris Johnson suggests building a bridge to FranceWhat is this mans obsession with bridges ! Boris Johnson gave his backing to not one but two Brexit bridges in . In February he spoke out in favour of a bridge across the channel linking the UK with France as an alternative to the tunnel. The idea was ruled out in the s but Mr Johnson insists the technology has moved on. Then in June the former Foreign Secretary said an idea for a pound billion bridge between Scotland and Northern Ireland should be seriously considered. Plans for a garden bridge- one of Johnsons many plans consigned to the rubbish heap, cost the taxpayer poundm.  Remember him  Following weeks of scandal about his private le Bolton was ousted when two-thirds of members voted against him. The former soldiers relationship with -year-old Jo Marney came under scrutiny after she caused outcry by saying Prince Harrys black American fianceacutee will taint the Royal Family with her seed and pave the way for a black king. Mr Bolton reportedly broke up with her after learning of the messages. But it later emerged the pair were secretly still dating and a member of the public snapped them on the tube. . Gavin Williamson tells Russia to go away and shut up following the Skripal poisoning  The Tory minister was asked at an event in Bristol whether he would consider a military response” to Russia after ex-spySergei Skripaland his daughter were exposed to a nerve agent. He did not rule it out but also said Britain should not be “rushing to do too much too rapidly”. He said: We’ll look at how Russia responds to what we have done It is atrocious and outrageous what Russia did in Salisbury. We have responded to that. Frankly Russia should go away, it should shut up. . Newsnight denies photoshopping Jeremy Corbyns hat to make it look more Russian  The BBC dismissed complaints that Newsnight altered a photo of Jeremy Corbyn to make him look more Russian. Thursdays show used a graphic of the Labour leader next to images of Moscow as the backdrop to an item about his response to the Salisbury poisoning. Critics said his hat was digitally altered and it was all designed to make him look like a Soviet stooge. Left wing commentator Owen Jones told the programme: “The media framing has been a disgrace and I have to say that includes your own program,” Jones said during his appearance. Yesterday the background of your program you had Jeremy Corbyn dressed up against the Kremlin skyline, dressed up as a Soviet stooge. “You even photoshopped his hat to look more Russian. People should complain to the BBC about that kind of thing.” But the topical news programme insisted they had used the same backdrop alongside a picture of Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson and the only thing they changed about the hat was the colour saturation. In April the Mirror reported claims made by Dominic Raabs then diary secretary about how she was working as an escort on the side. But the element of the story that seemed to capture the imagination of Westminster was her claim that Mr Raab ate the same lunch everyday - something he later denied. The woman claimed: “He has the same sandwich every day. He has the same lunch. “He has the same baguette with the same smoothie with a pot of fruit everyday. “It’s from Pret. He has the chicken Caesar and bacon baguette, superfruit pot and the vitamin volcano smoothie every day. “He is so weird. I get it for him. I go to Pret. That’s how I know. It’s the Dom Raab Special.” It wasnt long before the Dom Raab special became a thing. . Labour loses hundreds of thousands of pounds trying to organise a music festivalLast year Jeremy Corbyn clearly enjoyed the Glastonbury audience chanting his name. So what could be so hard about Labour organising its own festival. Those who attended the Labour Live certainly had fun but it proved a financial and PR disaster for the party. The festival, which was originally expecting to welcome , people to North London, had reportedly sold just , tickets with around a month to go. Ticket prices were slashed from pound to pound and the unions stepped in buying batches which they distributed to their members. Its understood the party lost around poundm on the event. But Party chairman Ian Lavery that they would be hosting the festival in  - and it would be twice as big. . Giant Donald Trump baby blimp greeted the President  It is almost certainly not the welcome the US President was hoping for - or expecting but Donald Trumps visit inspired tens of thousands of people to take to the streets in protest. And floating high above Parliament Square was the six-metre tall balloon which portrayed Trump as an angry infant, complete with a nappy and a whisp of blonde hair.   Donald Trump didnt exactly appear a natural when he met his herothe Queenfor the first time this afternoon. The US President met the monarch at Windsor Castle as part of his four-day working visit of the UK - and part of the historic meeting involved inspecting the troops together. It was a baking hot day and the -year-old was forced to stand in the sun waiting for Mr Trump to arrive. Then as he joined her to inspect the Coldstream Guards, he walked in front with the monarch dwarfed by his large frame. The Queen did not miss a beat and quickly moved to Mr Trumps other side while, for his part, he seemed none the wiser.  Theresa May dancing in Africa - not once but twiceTheresa May showed off her dance moves a second time on her trip to Africa. Despite some less than complimentary critiques of her boogeying on down with schoolkids in Cape Town, the Prime Minister took the opportunity to bust a move when she met some scouts in Nairobi. But Mrs May, who awkwardly swayed in South Africa, looked much more relaxed in Kenya. She waved her arms and rocked her hips, learning dance moves from the young scouts - and she even seemed to be smiling as she moved.   The Tory Attorney General, and more importantly, the warm up act forTheresa Mays keynote speech to Conservative Party Conference certainly made those in the hall sit up and listen. And to be honest, he didnt need a microphone. Most residents of the Midlands could have popped their heads out of an upstairs window and heard his booming, silken tones wafting on the wind. He was little known beforehand but Mr Coxs performance at Tory Conference, and later when he explained his Brexit legal advice to the Commons, will not be easily forgotten.  Theresa May dances again and it was just as awkward as youd expect   Theresa May danced onto the stage to Abbas Dancing Queen in nod to her embarrassing dancing on a trip to Africa. The Prime Minister made a joke at her own expense as she beganher speech to the Tory Party Conference. Mrs May twisted her hips and swung her arms as she entered the Symphony Hall in Birmingham. It was a deliberate nod to the embarrassing moves she flaunted on an official trip to Africa.  Dominic Raab admitted he hadnt understood importance of trade with France  At the time Dominic Raab was Brexit Secretary when he revealed he hadnt understood the importance of trade with France. Seventeen per cent of the UK’s trade in goods, or pound billion annually, goes through Dover to either Calais or Dunkirk, according to port officials. He also spoke about the peculiar, frankly, geographic, economic entity that is the United Kingdom with many on social media mocking him for Speaking at a London tech event, Mr Raab said: “I hadn’t quite understood the full extent of this, butyou look at the UK and you look at how we trade in goods, we are particularly reliant on the Dover-Calais crossing. He was widely mocked for the comments.  Karen Bradley admits she didnt know the basics of Northern Irish politics  In another example of a government minister all over their brief Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley admitted before taking on the job she was slightly scared of the region and didnt understand its politics. She said she didnt realise hat nationalists did not vote for unionists and that unionists did not vote for nationalists - which could be considered the very basic details about Northern Ireland. “I freely admit that when I started this job, I didn’t understand some of the deep-seated and deep-rooted issues that there are in Northern Ireland,” Ms Bradley told House magazine. “I didn’t understand things like when elections are fought, for example, in Northern Ireland – people who are nationalists don’t vote for unionist parties and vice versa. So, the parties fight for election within their own community. “Actually, the unionist parties fight the elections against each other in unionist communities and nationalists in nationalist communities.” Oh dear.  The European Research Group struggle to count to   Tory Brexiteers had to admit their bid to topple Theresa May embarrassingly flopped because of infighting in their ranks. Tory MP Steve Baker said there was “a tactical disagreement” among supporters of the hardline European Research Groupof Tory Brexiteers, over when to force a no-confidence vote in Mrs May’s leadership. Jacob Rees-Mogg, who chairs the group, called on supporters to submit letters to Tory backbench chief Sir Graham Brady. But reports that they had reached the crucial  appeared unfounding and the group were compared to Dads Army for their botched coup.  Government loses three votes in just over an hour and is held in contempt - for first time in history  Theresa May lost a humiliating hat-trick of defeats in  minutes. Labour said Mrs May was “in office but not in power” as she suffered three setbacks in just over one hour:.pm: MPs vote by  to  to block a government bid to boot the legal advice into the long grass. .pm:  to , finding the Government in contempt of Parliament by refusing to reveal the advice. .pm:  to  for an amendment by Tory remainer Dominic Grieve, giving MPs a greater say in Brexitthe PM’s plan is defeated next week.Lets just say it was not the best hour of the Prime Ministers le.  Labour MP picks up the mace  Lloyd Russell-Moyle was booted out of the House of Commons after picking up a ceremonial mace in protest at the Governments handling ofBrexit. Hiscolleagueslet out audible gasps of horror as he grabbed the large symbolic item and attempted to walk out of the room with it held aloft. The Brighton MP put up no resistance as handed over the mace before being ordered to leave the chamber for the day by Speaker John Bercow. Mr Russell-Moyles actions came after Theresa May delayed the Brexit deal vote, something he vocally opposed in earlier exchanges. It should also be remembered that Mr Russell-Moyle made history this year when he became the first MP to tell the House of Commons he was HIV+.  Theresa May survives no confidence vote - and buys herself some much needed extra time  A weakened Theresa May clung to power after promising Tory MPs she would not lead the party into another general election. But an eye-watering  voted against her compared to  in her favour - more than a third of all her MPs. In a defiant statement outside  Downing Street she claimed she had listened - but also vowed to get on with the job and claimed she had a renewed mission. MPs cheered uproariously in the Commons packed, oak-led Committee Room  as the result was revealed to a smiling chief whip. Tory Party rules mean she cant be challenged for another year. Mrs May earned herself a temporary respite but there are other ways she could be toppled. The Christmas recess could not come soon enough for the embattled PM. But when she s the small problem of the Brexit deal will not have gone away.

title: 52 christmas facts you never
story: News Christmas facts you never knew about the festive periodThink you know everything about the most wonderful time of the year  Here are  facts to get you even more in the mood for Christmas Day ShareCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsChristmas Crackers"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter queuing up to get your turkey, you arrive home only to find the cat has swallowed most of the tinsel and you completely forgot to buy any tangerines. But have you ever stopped to wonder how these traditions started - why we kiss under the mistletoe, or give each other stockings full of goodies  Here are  festive facts to get you even more in the mood for Christmas. . Speedy Santa US scientists calculated that Santa visits  homes a second to deliver all the worlds presents on Christmas Eve, travelling at  miles a second. . Robins Robins on cards were a joke  years ago when postmen wore red tunics and were named after them.  . Mince Pies Although now mostly vegetarian, in Victorian times, mince pies were made with beef and spices. . Tangerines The tradition of putting tangerines in stockings comes from th-century French nuns who left socks full of fruit, nuts and tangerines at the houses of the poor.  . Three Wise Men  Despite the tale of three wise men paying homage to baby Jesus, the Bible never gives a number. Matthews Gospel refers to merely wise men. . Wassailing Carols began as an old English custom called wassailing, toasting neighbours to a long le. . Carols Carols werent sung in churches until they were introduced by St Francis of Assisi in the th century. . Stockings Hanging stockings out comes from the Dutch custom of leaving shoes packed with food for St Nicholass donkeys. He would leave small gts in . . Angels Singing  There is no reference to angels singing anywhere in the Bible.  . Christmas Trees Nearly  million Christmas trees are grown each year in Europe. . Noel The word Noel derives from the French expression les bonnes nouvelles or the good news. . Baby Jesus Jesus was probably born in a cave and not a wooden stable, say Biblical scholars. . Xmas The abbreviation Xmas isnt irreligious. The letter X is a Greek abbreviation for Christ. . Tallest Tree The worlds tallest Xmas tree at ft high was erected in a Washington shopping mall in . . White Christmas The chances of a white Christmas are changing all the time. Bookmaker Coral had odds at - for it to be the coldest winter since records began. Theyre also giving - odds that snow will fall in London before the end of November.  . The Birth of Jesus Many theologians estimate that Jesus wasnt born on December  but sometime in September between BC and AD. . Jingle Bells James Pierponts  song Jingle Bells was first called One Horse Open Sleigh and was written for Thanksgiving. . Turkey Before turkey, the traditional Christmas meal in England was a pigs head and mustard. . Banning Christmas In , after the English Civil War, Oliver Cromwell banned festivities. The law wasnt lted until . . Worlds Biggest Snowman In , residents of the state of Maine in America built the worlds biggest ever snowman. He stood at ft tall. . A Merry Greek Christmas The Greeks celebrate Christmas on January , according to the old Julian calendar, while Xmas presents are opened on New Years Day. . Eating a Christmas Tree Many parts of the Christmas tree can actually be eaten, with the needles being a good source of Vitamin C. . Holly The holly in a wreath symbolises Christs crown of thorns while the red berries are drops of his blood. . Christmas Cards The first commercial Christmas cards were commissioned by civil servant Sir Henry Cole in London in . Featuring a family drinking wine, one sold for #, last year. . Hanging Presents Hanging presents on trees may come from the Druids who believed the tree was the giver of all good things.  . Christmas Crackers The largest Christmas cracker - .m long and .m in diameter - was pulled in Australia in . Best Christmas crackers for  including everything from the unusual to luxury . Shopping Spree The long shopping spree before Christmas began in America when relatives of soldiers posted overseas in the Second World War were encouraged to mail gts early. . Christmas Songs Jingle Bells was the first song broadcast from space when Gemini  astronauts Tom Stafford and Wally Schirra sang it on December , . . Christmas Comets Astronomers believe the Star Of Bethlehem, which guided the wisemen to Jesus, may have been a comet or the planet Uranus. . The Many Names of Santa Santa has dferent names around the world - Kriss Kringle in Germany, Le Befana in Italy, Pere Noel in France and Deushka Morozin Russia. . Christs Mass The word Christmas comes from the Old English Cristes maesse meaning Christs Mass. . Bing Cosby The bestselling Xmas single ever is Bing Crosbys White Christmas, shting over million copies worldwide since . . title: children sleep bristol airport baggage
story: NewsChildren sleep on Bristol Airport baggage carousel after being locked in overnightPassengers at Bristol Airport were frustrated after being stuck in the baggage reclaim all for hours in the middle of the nightShareCommentsByTristan CorkKelly-Ann Mills:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsFrustrated passengers and tired children wait on baggage carousel "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrustrated passengers have slammed Bristol Airport after they were left waiting for hours in the middle of the night for their bags. People arriving at the airport on Sunday evening were delayed taking off for their flights to Bristol. But after arriving later than planned they they faced a wait of more than three hours to get their bags from the planes. The baggage reclaim area was reportedly full of ‘tired and grumpy’ passengers, with children sleeping on the baggage carousel. Passengers claimed they were ‘locked in’ the reclaim hall for hours, Bristol Live reports. Airport bosses said there were a number of ‘off-schedule flights’ arriving at the time, which caused a backlog in baggage handling. A spokesman promised a review into what went wrong. But frustrated passengers lambasted the airport and the baggage handling set-up on Twitter, with one even claiming it was quicker to sort out the Brexit deal than get the baggage off the planes. Twitter user Steve first began to complain after waiting for an hour and a half for his bags to emerge from a flight into Bristol from Berlin. “Whats going on  ” he asked Bristol Airport. “Meeting Berlin flight waiting for mins for luggage!! Unacceptable.”  Then, while the wait continued and more passengers arrived, he said: “An hour and three quarters now. This is the bread and butter of your job and you clearly arent capable of doing it. Its not like a load of unexpected planes can turn up! “Two hours now - you realize Santa will be unloading gt billion presents tomorrow night. Might be worth askinghe does training,” he joked. Finally, the bags from the Berlin flight began to arrive on the carousel. “Two hours  mins in the end - Mrs May makes faster progress on Brexit than that!” he said. Darren Sainty said his flight in from Paris had been delayed by four hours in France, and then the bags took three hours to be unloaded off the plane. He described ‘children sleepingbaggage belts’. And Rachel Baker complained her simple one-hour flight from Glasgow to Bristol turned into a nightmare. “Thanks for such a fun night,” she said. “Look at all these happy faces, at Glasgow airport at pm for a one-hour flight, past am and still waiting for our luggage in Bristol. Locked in a room with no information and nowhere to sit, she added. The delays were also felt by friends and family waiting on the other side of the passport control in the arrivals hall. Pat Seymour was one, who waited for hours for her son to emerge from the Berlin flight. He arrived on an easyJet flight from Berlin, he landed at midnight and came through baggage reclaim at .am, she said. I was the other side waiting for one of the tired, grumpy people. I can certainly testy to weary passengers and exhausted children coming through from baggage reclaim when they eventually got their luggage.  The only people available to speak to were security staff and the young lady on the information desk. One lady who was waiting asked herit would be possible to speak to the Swissport duty manager and was informed that they were probably in the baggage hall. I don’t knowshe did manage to get anyone to come and speak to her, but my son said there was no one there to speak to about the situation when I asked him, she added. Pierluigi Stanzione was waiting for his -year-old mum to arrive for Christmas from Naples. She was due to arrive at Bristol Airport at .pm on Sunday evening, but didnt actually take off from the southern Italiian city until .pm. She didnt get off the plane until midnight, but her baggage didnt arrive in the baggage hall until .am. No one said a word until my mum complained and only at that point passengers were told that the flight was delayed so there was no staff from Swissport to unload the luggage, he said. A spokesperson for Bristol Airport apologised to passengers. “Sorry for the delay that you experienced,” passengers were told. “This was caused by a number of off schedule flights arriving at the time. Airport staff were in location to assist with information and queries. On behalf of your airline we apologise for the delay,” she added. A spokesperson told Bristol Live: Delays were experienced to the arrival of passengers baggage overnight Sunday, December  and Monday, December  to a small number of flights. This was caused due to flight disruption across the flight schedule earlier in the day. As a result of the knock-on effect with the delayed flights arriving off scheduled, airline ground handling resources were stretched at times, meaning some passengers experienced baggage delays. We continue to work with our airline handling partners to limit the inconvenience caused to passengers. Airline handling and customer service staff were present in the baggage reclaim area assisting during the delay. Bristol Airport apologises and appreciates the frustration passengers experienced due to the delay in the arrival of their bags. An internal investigation with the airline handling agent will be completed, she added. The baggage handling at Bristol Airport is done by a company called Swissport. “We are aware that there were a signicant number of flights arriving off schedule at Bristol airport on the evening of the rd and early on the th, causing a knock-on impact to baggage reclaim for passengers, said a Swissport spokesperson. “We work closely with our airline and airport partners to mitigate the impact of these schedule disruptions to passengers and we understand these delays were frustrating to passengers during this busy holiday period, he added.

If motorists can’t see  metres ahead they need to be driving at less than mph.” People hoping to escape motoring misery were warned to plan ahead due to planned engineering works on train lines. title: how long take cook turkey
story: NewsHow long does it take to cook turkey for Christmas dinner  Roasting times and tipsGetting everything on the table at the same time is no mean feat so it pays to plan aheadyou are celebrating Christmas Day  with a roast turkey dinner and all the trimmingsShareCommentsByAnn GripperExecutive Editor:,  DEC NewsIts turkey time! But how long will it take to cook your Christmas dinner  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Roast turkey is the traditional centrepiece of the British Christmas dinner and also American Thanksgiving - but with so many dishes to have ready at the same time, getting it there is a triumph of organisation.Preparations may start the night beforeto get the stuffing ready and the turkey preparedan early lunchtime celebration is to be ready on time.The traditional Christmas dinner includes turkey, stuffing, roast potatoes, cranberry sauce and of course the flaming Christmas pudding. So it is important to get the main centrepiece perfect before you start worrying about all the trimmings.Many Americans would say a traditional Thanksgiving dinner is incomplete without cranberry sauce, stuffing or dressing, mashed potatoes, gravy and of course pumpkin pie. But as most people roast a turkey only once or twice a year -that - it is understandablethe detail of what to do with it has got a little rusty. We have some handy tips to help you get dinner on the table in time. When will my turkey be done Crucial to any roast is how long it takes to cook the meat. This is worked out by the weight of the joint . The turkey should be at room temperature before cooking.For a roast turkey weighing less than kg, British Turkey recommends  minutes per kilogram plus  minutes at C , GM, F.Birds weighing more than kg require  minutes per kilogram plus  minutes at that temperature. And always make sure you check its cooked through . Dont forget to allow time for the meat to rest too -  to  minutes. Loosely covered with foil it will stay warm while you can get on with the vegetables. When you know what time your turkey should be cooked you can work out the rest of your Thanksgiving dinner cooking timetable. Oh yes, defrosting my turkey would be a good idea. How long will that take British Turkey estimates a kg turkey will take  hours to defrost.So much for timings, how can I tellthe turkey really is cooked  All ovens y, and moving other dishes around in the oven will affect the temperature, so you still need to check the bird is actually cooked rather than just relying on timings. The juices should run clear when the thickest part of the thigh is pierced with a skewer. If you have a temperature probe it should measure C or above in the thickest part of the breast. What should I do to make it really tasty  MasterChefs John Torode likes to fill his turkey with water while Mary Berry likes to spread hers with butter.And Asda have put together a video guide for preparing the perfect turkey in five minutes. If youre ready to start planning for the festive season, visit our Christmas dinner page for more top tips and recipes from the experts.

title: how to make roast potatoes
story: NewsHow to make the best roast potatoes - top tips to guarantee crispinessHeston Blumenthal has a few tips for how to make the perfect roast potatoesShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience WriterJoshua Barrie:,  DEC NewsSave on spuds: Roast potatoes and sprouts are both down in price from last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMost of us reckon we can absolutely nail roast potatoes, but although we have our tried and tested methods sometimes theyre just not as good as they were last time. Every now and again, what you hoped would be a perfect tray of roasties , has been a little disappointing. And with Christmas just around the corner, the last thing you want is less-than-perfect potatoes on the day - especiallyyouve got family to impress. Luckily for you, none other than Heston Blumenthal has some top tips on how to get it right - and we reckon he knows his stuff on this one. Heres three essential tips for roasting your potatoes to perfection, and theyre so simple that theres really no excuse for getting it wrong next time.  Number one, make sure you parboil those badboys. Most cooks know to boil before roasting. Season the pan, leave the spuds to cook, then throw them in a baking tray with oil or fat, salt, pepper, maybe a sprig of rosemary and a couple of garlic cloves. But theres a major issue when it comes to timing, according to three Michelin-starred chef Heston Blumenthal. Heston advises leaving potatoes in to boil for  minutes before roasting - which is longer than most of us do as it almost cooks them through. He also suggests putting the peelings in the cooking water to improve the flavour. Good idea.  Number two, you need to scuff up those potatoes as you drain them to make sure they go extra crispy. You could do this by giving them a bit of a shake in the colander, but dont do it too hard. Basically, you want them to crumble just a little, so that the oil or fat covers a wider surface area and penetrates deeper into the potato. If you really want that crispiness, this genius tip is guaranteed to get results - and it may seem a little unusual. What you need to do is score the potatoes with a fork. This creates ridges and grooves, perfect for golden, crispy goodness. Thirdly, Heston also says that metal baking trays are best. Avoid glass or Pyrex. Metal is a better conductor, so the oil will get hotter faster, which means a crispier exterior. Have you got a hot tip for perfect roast potatoes  Let us know in the comments!

Footage released by the RSPCA shows a man getting out of the car, tossing a dog bed on the pavement and leading the white and black Staff before unclipping its lead and running back to the vehicle. Now, hundreds of people, including celebs, have offered to give Snoop a home after more than a million watched the clip posted online, StokeonTrentLive reports.  BBC political presenter Andrew Neil wrote on Twitter: So disturbed by this footage. I say to RSPCAyou have trouble re-homing this little dog, I will take it gladly.I have been in tears. It was how the little dog tried to get back in the car that killed me. There are shelters all over the UK who can help find your pet a new home. This is the most upsetting video to watch. RSPCA inspector Natalie Perehovsky said: “The footage has to be seen to be believed, it’s just awful.To see the poor dog in such obvious distress jumping up at the car as it drives away it just heartbreaking. title: man eats only mince pies
story: NewsMan eats only mince pies for every meal in December - and LOSES weightPadraig Howard replaced every meal with mince pies in a  day festive challenge from December  until Christmas Day and lost nearly half a stoneShareCommentsByRichard Percival:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsPadraig Howard stuffs his face with a mince pie"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who ate nothing but mince pies from December st to the th says he has lost weight - and vowed never to eat one again. Padraig Howard, , loves the festive treats so much he took on the mammoth challenge for charity. He replaced every meal with mince pies in a  day festive challenge from December  until Christmas Day. The behavioural support worker has scoffed  mince pies - , calories - yet lost a staggering kgand now weighs kg. He ate around  a day and ate them whenever he got peckish rather than at assigned meal times.   Pod, from Belsize Park, London said: You dont realise the importance of how your eating habits influence your health until you do something stupid. I dont think I will be having anymore mince pies. Inspired by the documentary Super Size Me, which sees a man eat McDonalds three times a day, Pod ditched all other food for the  day period. Pod said: Ive always loved mince pies and last year I ate a lot of them over last Christmas. So much so my friends even pointed out how many Id been eating and we started joking about the idea of doing some sort of food challenge for charity. Like the guy from Super Size Me, who eat nothing but McDonalds, except Id eat nothing but mince pies over December. He purchased the festive treats from supermarkets including Tesco, Sainsburys and Morrisons, as well as Pret a Manger - who gave him some freebies - and independent bakeries.   Pod said: To begin with I tried consuming my normal calories in mince pie form but I really struggled with my sugar levels, so now I just snack as and when Im hungry. I went and got a big stockpile of mince pies from all your typical high street shops, Tesco, Morrisons, Sainsburys, Ive also been eating them from bakerys and cafes. Morrisons apple turnover mince pies were probably the best of high street names but the best mince pies I had were from a bakery called Konditor and Cook in London. Pod has since raised more than pound, for Crisis, a charity which helps homeless people in London. Pod said: The reception I have had from the challenge has been incredible and overwhelming. I chose this charity because homelessness is on the rise and it felt particularly important around this time of year with the weather getting colder.   It must be incredibly dficult living on streets, with people getting festive and jolly all around you for Christmas. If I give a someone homeless some food, it might be a sweet treat like a mince pie, evenits not something they wont eat, they may have no choice. I thought it would be an interesting challenge for me mentally and physically, not to suggest I have it as bad as someone whos homeless, but limiting my diet will make me understand what its like to have no food choices. He chronicled his journey on his Instagram page SuperPiesMe to raise money for homelessness charity Crisis and is scoffing about ten a day. People can donate to Pods challenge until January  by visiting www.justgiving fundraising superpiesme.

James Brookes, royal commentator at Royal Central, told the Express: “As with other royal engagements and visits, there’s a pecking order. “The more junior members of the family arrive first, with the senior royal following.”  So Meghan and Harry arrived before Kate and William, as they are more junior members of the family. Today starts with breakfast – for the royal women it is breakfast in bed as the men eat together downstairs.  The family then walk to the Norfolk estate’s St Mary Magdalene Church for the service, where they are greeted by a throng of well-wishers. The family sit at pm for shrimp salad, turkey with all the trimmings and Christmas pudding with brandy butter. After lunch, all watch the Queen’s speech. In a new ITV documentary  Meghan - The Story So Far , royal biographer Andrew Morton revealed that when Kate becomes Queen, Meghan will have to curtsy in her presence. The revelation was explained in the Tonight special, where Morton speaks candidly about Meghans current role in the royal family. He said: Kate has established herself as the future Queen. story: NewsMeghan Markles hair is hiding big clue about the royal babys due dateRoyal fans think Meghan Markles pregnancy due date might be much sooner than expected - and its all because of her hairShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  DEC NewsMeghan Markle is said to be expecting her baby in Spring  "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSince news broke in October that Meghan Markle was expecting her first child with Prince Harry, royal fans have been desperate to find out when the baby will be born. In the announcement, made by Kensington Palace, it was said the child will be born in Spring . But since then, the Palace has been very careful not to give away any more information about the birth.  This hasnt stopped people from speculating about the Duchess of Sussexs due date - with one beauty expert recently coming up with a way to work it out for ourselves. Jane Mayhead, Senior Trichology Consultant at The Private Clinic of Harley Street, told Express that the clue is in Meghans hair. She said: In a number of recent images of Meghan, her hair certainly appears much fuller than before the pregnancy and its possible that this is due to changing hormone levels. The increased levels of hormones during pregnancy can cause the growth cycle of the hair to increase, meaning the hair is less frequently renewed and replaced at the site of the follicle and women will experience thicker and shinier hair.  Jane continued that many pregnant women find their hair becomes more voluminous two thirds of the way through their pregnancy. I tend to find that most women will experience some level of increased volume by around the six month mark. If she is correct about this, then it means Meghan could have her baby in late February or early March. This will be earlier than thought, as many have speculated the baby will be born in April.  However pregnancy may not be the only thing having an impact on Meghans hair - she may have changed her hair care routine to protect her baby. She added: There are, of course, other possibilities to consider. It is highly likely that Meghan may also be avoiding putting harsh chemicals in her hair. Moreover she could have changed her diet to include an intake of folic acid, which is particularly good for hair growth.

story: NewsMeghan Markle shows off growing baby bump as she hugs royal fans at SandringhamPregnant Meghan Markle, whose due date is next spring, wowed royal fans before the Christmas church service alongside Prince Harry, Kate Middleton and Prince WilliamShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror am celebrity-news video william-kate-harry-meghan-reunited-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markles growing baby bump was the centre of attention as fans of the Royal Family gushed over her at Sandringham. The time-honoured tradition was led once again by the -year-old Queen at the church in the grounds of her private Norfolk country getaway. story: NewsMum spends a thousand pounds to put on a Christmas dinner for lonely peopleMum-of-two Mo Fayose and a group of  volunteers cooked up a feast at a sheltered housing complex in NottinghamShareByMark CardwellLouie Smith:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA selfless mum organised a Christmas dinner for more than  isolated and lonely people. Mo Fayose, , and a group of  volunteers have cooked up a feast at a sheltered housing complex today. They served turkey, chicken, fish, caullower soup, butternut squash and swede soup, salmon canapeacutes, garlic and herb canapeacutes - and of course Brussels sprouts. Mo, who has been holding similar events for several years, spent over pound of her own money paying for the food. The mum-of-two said: “This is for people who are isolated - who can’t get out of the house, elderly people, people with children. “The oldest person who has attended has been . “When people start seeing Christmas stuff on the shelves and the lights go up, it sends people into depression.   “Butthey know there is a group of them in the community, it makes them happy. “I use a mobile cooker in the garden of the building with a marquee. “I have volunteers, and we decorate it aswe are having a wedding. Mo planned to host her first public Christmas meal at her Nottingham home several years ago. But the idea “went viral” forcing her to find a bigger venue and enlist the help of volunteers. This years event cost more than pound, to put on, with  per cent of the funds provided by Mo and the rest coming from charitable donations. As well as hosting the care home meal the team also delivered Christmas dinners to those in the community.  Charity worker Mo added: “I got the idea for it when I was doing my mental health nursing degree. “I was so excited because it was Christmas - but one patient said to me ‘stop it, woman - not everybody likes Christmas’. “She said she wasn’t looking forward to Christmas because it’s a lonely time. “I then did research into festive loneliness, and found out many people would rather be in hospital than at home, because they wouldn’t be on their own on Christmas day. “I now do this throughout the year for elderly people and people in independent living.   “I am orced, and I was lonely as well - I didn’t realise until I started doing this. “I find it fascinating to come together with people who all share similar journeys with me. This year, Mo fell into hot water when Nottingham City Council ordered her to take down flyers she had posted around the city advertising the event. But the council, which had previously praised her work, later backed down and allowed her to continue posting her material. Councillor Linda Woodings, representing the Basford ward of Nottingham, said it was a really worthy cause and there had been a genuine misunderstanding.

story: NewsMum who mistakenly gave daughter advent calendar for CATS hits back at online abuseJess Evans shared her story intending to be light-hearted and says she did not want to open herself up to abuseShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsJess accidentally bought this calendar for her daughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who accidentally bought her daughter an advent calendar meant for cats has hit back at abuse shes had online after she shared her story. Full-time mum Jess Evans initially assumed her nine-year-old daughter was just being fussy when she didnt get past day four of the calendar. But she soon discovered there was a very good reason why Alissa had given up on the green-tinged goodies. After taking a closer look at the calendar, the mum-of-three was horried to discover that the apple flavoured chocolates she thought shed given her child, were actually made of yoghurt and catnip - and were intended to be consumed by cats. Jess took to social media to explain what had happened with the intention of making people laugh in the lead up to Christmas. But not everyone found it funny, leading the mum to hit back, saying her intention was not to open herself up to abuse.  She told the Shropshire Star: We havent made any money from this story, its intention was a light hearted article to make people laugh in the lead up to Christmas, not to open myself up to abuse . The calender does state for cats on the front but be honest who reads a calendar that was put on the same shelf as the chocolate ones presumably by a customer.I didnt pick it up down the cat section and think to myself this will do. Alissa had eaten four of the chocolates before deciding she couldnt stomach any more - but she is fine. Telling the story earlier, Jess, who lives in Oswestry, Shropshire, said: I was in shock and felt like the worst mother ever when I realised Id bought her a calendar for cats. She said they tasted a bit strange, but hadnt said they were horrible, so I just forgot about it.  The -year-old continued: Alissa hadnt been eating them for a few days and when I asked why she brought the box over to me. When I turned the calendar over and read it was yoghurt and catnip flavour I couldnt believe it - and that it had taken  days for us to notice. I have a degree in English literature and creative writing but still couldnt read a calendar. The mum purchased the pound. advent calendar from the Oswestry branch of BM while out shopping with Alissa and her younger sisters Alexis Davies-Evans, three and -month-old Aurora Davies-Evans.   She says she got the younger girls Peppa Pig and My Little Pony advent calendars, but wanted to find a dferent one for her eldest child. I was rushing around at the last minute with all three of them Christmas shopping and went into BM where all the advent calenders were and picked it up without reading it. She added: Once [Alissa] got over the shock she found the funny side of it. Thankfully shes absolutely fine and Ive checked online that she will be ok.

story: NewsQueens Christmas speech LEAKED on YouTube hours before it airs on TVA five-minute, -second clip showing the Queens address has surfaced on social media and websitesShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video what-exactly-queens-christmas-speech-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queens entire Christmas speech has been leaked online hours before millions sit down to watch it on TV. A five-minute, -second clip was posted on YouTube and shared on a number of websites and social media accounts. It emerged as the Royal Family prepared for its annual Christmas Day service at the -year-old Queens Sandringham country estate in Norfolk. Buckingham Palace has kept the speech a secret, releasing a photo of the Queen sat in her lavish White Drawing Room and a few excerpts of what she said in the recording. It will be shown on TV at pm. According to Buckingham Palace, the Queen will say in her Christmas message that the festivals message of peace and goodwill needs to be heeded as much as ever, and people should respect each other even when they harbour the most deeply held dferences.  She will also speak of family and friendship following a year in which her grandson Prince Harry married US-born actress Meghan Markle, who is pregnant with the couples first child. Speaking about the birth of Jesus, she will say: I believe his message of peace on earth and goodwill to all is never out of date. It can be heeded by everyone its needed as much as ever. Even with the most deeply held dferences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good step towards greater understanding.  She will also say: Through the many changes I have seen over the years, faith, family and friendship have been not only a constant for me but a source of personal comfort and reassurance. Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the leak.has chosen not to reveal details that were not officially released through the Palace. The Queen issued a writ against The Sun after it published the full text of her  broadcast two days before transmission. She later accepted an apology and a pound, donation to charity. Her Christmas broadcast is a traditional feature of the festive season where the head of state can express her thoughts about the past year.  The monarch made her first Christmas broadcast live on the radio in  - the year of her accession - and the annual message was first shown on TV in . She has made a Christmas Day speech every year except in , when she decided the royals had been on TV enough after an unprecedented family documentary. Instead, her greeting took the form of a written address. The first televised broadcast was transmitted live from the Long Library at Sandringham, and the Queen told how she hoped this new medium will make my Christmas message more personal and more direct. The Queens first pre-recorded speech was in .   The monarch usually completes her delivery in one take. The Queens grandfather, King George V, delivered the first royal Christmas broadcast live on the radio from Sandringham in . He read a message composed by author Rudyard Kipling. The original idea was suggested by Sir John Reith, the founding father of the BBC, to inaugurate the Empire Service, now the BBC World Service. The speech is written by the Queen herself and is one of the rare occasions when she does not turn to the Government for advice and is able to voice her own views. Each message has a strong religious framework and reflects current issues. She chooses a theme, drawing sometimes on her own personal experiences and sometimes from global events such as wars, terrorist attacks or natural disasters.

title: what royal family christmas day
story: NewsWhat the Royal Family do on Christmas Day - including chats with Queen and fancy mealsThe Queen will be joined by Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle, Princes William and Harry, Princess Charlotte, George and little Louis for the Christmas breakShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  DEC NewsIts a special day for the royal family "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEvery family has their own traditions on Christmas Day. Just like the rest of us, the Royal Family come together to spend the special day together - and a lot of their traditions arent too much dferent to the ones us normal folk enjoy. They tuck into a big turkey dinner , eat Christmas cake and exchange presents. But there also a few extra special traditions thrown in there - well, they are royal after all.  Heres a full step-by-step guide to what the Royal Family get up to on Christmas Day. Christmas Eve Afternoon tea Once the family have all arrived and unpacked, they gather for afternoon tea. Its believed to be a formal occasion, with the men in black tie and the women wearing gowns and jewels. Opening presents To incorporate their German heritage into the festivities, the family open their presents on Christmas Eve as is traditional in the country. Shortly after they arrive they all lay their gts out on dferent tables, so each guest has their own little pile. Prince Philip oversees organising the gts and tells everyone when they can open them. The family exchange cheap joke presents, and in the past Kate bought Harry a Grow your Own Girlfriend Kit and the Prince got his granny a Les a B**** shower cap.  Christmas Day Breakfast The royals kick off the big day with breakfast, but many of the couples split up for the first festive meal. According to former royal chef Darren McGrady the women tend to eat in their rooms while the men sit together downstairs. Speaking to the Daily Mail, he said: On Christmas Day, the ladies generally opt for a light breakfast of sliced fruit, half a grapefruit, toast and coffee delivered to their rooms. The men on the other hand have a much heartier breakfast, usually including eggs, bacon, mushrooms, kippers and grilled kidneys. Trips to Church is the only time the Queen carries cash, and she normally pops either a fiver or a tenner in the collection pot - but it could be more at Christmas. The best time to do it is when shes seated at her card table, before and after dinner, she will sit and play Bridge or Canasta and shell always ask people to join her, thats your chance to get quality time and tell the monarch what youre thinking and feeling. Dinner Before long its time for ANOTHER meal, and the royal chefs put on an evening buffet for dinner. Former chef Darren McGrady said theres a buffet dinner with - dferent items. title: boy 3 walks two miles
story: NewsBoy, , walks two miles in minus C cold after watching dad drown on snowmobileYevgeny Vlasov, , and his son were walking by the bank of the River Gur in the Khabarovsk region of Russia when tragedy struckShareCommentsByLaura ForsythWill Stewart:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsFather Yevgeny Vlasov shouted to his boy to run before he went under "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little boy walked two miles across snowy wastes in minus C cold after watching his dad die when his snowmobile tumbled into an ice hole. The astonishing Christmas walk in the Khabarovsk region, Russia meant that the three-year-old saved himself from certain death. Yevgeny Vlasov, , had picked his son up from nursery and went with him to inspect an ice hole for fishing. He left the boy on the bank of the River Gur, some , miles east of Moscow, as he turned the snowmobile but it fell into the fast flowing river because the ice was not as thick as he had expected. The boy - not yet named - said his father shouted to him: “Son, run to the shop” before he went under. The family own a shop in Kenay village in Khabarovsk region - and the boy obediently followed his father’s final instruction.  Head of the village administration Yury Anekhov said: “The child saw his father sinking. “The boy later told me that his father shouted to him: Son, run to the shop!. “They have their own shop in the village, and Yevgeny told him to go there. “The boy climbed a hillock, and then came down from it - its height is about  metres . “Then he walked through the taiga.” The boy followed the tracks of his father’s snowmobile but then lost the path, reported The Siberian Times. He was walking in a temperature of minus C - colder than ever recorded in Britain. He mistakenly took a wrong track but by chance was spotted by a local man who used it as a shortcut.  The man said: “He doesn’t speak too well yet - he’s too young - so he couldn’t tell me what happened. “I just understood that it was something really bad, and rushed to the village to find his family.” The man said: “The little one was so smart. He had figured that the way back home was to follow the traces of his dad’s snowmobile.” He reunited the boy with his mother Maria. A day later the child succumbed to a “very strong fever”, he said. Vlasov was a successful local businessman owning a chain of shops. Local police chief Alexander Kolomytsev said that the chances of finding the body were slight. It was a “fast mountain river” and was impossible to use ers in the search.

The last major eruption was in .  In October,reported on how Mount Etna is slowly sliding into the sea and when it goes it could trigger a tsunami , according to research. Europes most famous volcano was already known to be edging slowly towards the Mediterranean. But the analysis showed the movement is mainly being driven by it collapsing under its own weight - a phenomenon known as gravitational instability. This has caused one of the sides of the notorious mountain on the east coast of Sicily to weaken, increasing the risk of a devastating tidal wave. Previously it had been commonly assumed the lava bubbling inside was the root cause.

title: after defeat by celtic dundee boss says this weeks games are the ones that really count
story: Moments after Dundee’s - defeat at Celtic Park, manager Jim McIntyre’s thoughts turned straight to what he calls “two huge games” this week.The Dark Blues were condemned to spend Christmas as the Premiership’s bottom side after champions Celtic swept them aside with embarrassing ease.The Dens gaffer was disappointed with the manner of his side’s defeat but acknowledged this week’s games against Livingston and St Johnstone are where Dundee have a better opportunity to pick up some much-needed points.He said: “My whole thought process is we have two huge games coming up at home.“We need to make sure we are picking up points in these two games. They’ll be huge for us.”To add to the Dark Blues’ woes, St Mirren picked up a victory at Motherwell to leave them three points adrt at the foot of the ision.Adding points to his own team’s total is more important to Jim, however – as is bringing in new faces next month.“What St Mirren do isn’t our concern,” Jim added.“It’s all about what we do and we have to make sure we continue to just think about ourselves.“The transfer window is going to be important for all of the clubs at the bottom, it’s an opportunity to try to get players in to help the ones we already have.”The Dark Blues did hold out against a dominant Celtic for almost the entire first half with his team’s organisation pleasing the manager, though the manner of the opening goal didn’t.He said: “It was a deserved scoreline.“Celtic were very good, their movement was so fluid, they caused us loads of problems.“I thought our organisation defensively was very good for  minutes but concentration levels are so important.“The timing of the goal and our player stopping for offside was the key disappointment.“It was onside, our video boy confirmed at half-time it was onside, so that was disappointing, just play to the whistle and argue about it later.“A couple of minutes before half-time you’re looking to get in at - and regroup, try to address where Celtic were hurting us.“In the second half Celtic were just too good for us, simple as that.”

title: bin collection plans change for christmas
story: Councils across Tayside and Fe have announced changes to recycling schedules during the festive period.Dundee City Council carried out collections today – and will do so again on Hogmanay – as normal.However, all other collections will be running a day behind over the Christmas and New Year weeks.It means that collections planned for Tuesday will take place on Wednesday instead, with New Year’s Day collections put back until January .Collections will also be held on Saturday instead of Friday.The city council’s recycling centres will also have dferent opening hours.A spokesman said: “The recycling centres at Riverside and Baldovie will be closed tomorrow and Wednesday, and on Tuesday January  and Wednesday January .“The centres will be open am-.pm on all other days .“Please note a permit system is in place for certain types of vehicles.“The Riverside composting site will be closed tomorrow and Wednesday, and on Tuesday January  and Wednesday January .”Special waste uplts have been suspended until Monday January .In Angus the council says there will be no collections on Christmas Day, Boxing Day, New Year’s Day or January .Residents have been encouraged to visit the Angus Council website to check revised collection plans for specic addresses.Perth and Kinross Council will operate a similar scheme to the one in Angus, with collections suspended tomorrow and Wednesday and the same days next week, with information available on its website about revised collection plans.Fe Council’s bin collection schemes also dfer based on location, with residents able to download calendars from the council’s website which offer specic information about their address.

title: cafe staff doing their buttie at christmas to show dundee is an amazing place
story: A Dundee takeaway is to offer free food and drink to the less fortunate on Christmas Day.Butties  on Albert Street will be open for business at .am when it will hand out free soup, hot rolls, tea and coffee to people in need.Manageress Sharon Tait, , said the shop had been planning the gesture since November in an effort to give a little back to the community.She added: “This is the first year we have decided to do this.“I’ve always wanted to volunteer at the soup kitchens in Dundee over Christmas.“Having a young family that hadn’t always been possible but they’ve grown up now.“I spoke to our director Ian Tait, and he was up for doing it.“It will only be the Stobswell premises that will be open but four of us will be in until am.”Sharon said the response they’ve had to the shop opening has been excellent, with plenty of donations coming in from suppliers and other businesses.She added: “We’ve already had donations from the Booker Group, Broxburn Browns and Pam’s Flowers.“The post that was put up on social media was shared more than , times.“I have been overwhelmed by the response. There have been some great stories recently of people in the city helping others.“Dundee is an amazing place.”Ian said he was right behind the idea and is hopeful plenty of people will benefit.He added: “When Sharon approached us we thought it was an excellent idea.“We’ve had an incredible response but maybe not everyone will have social media.“If anyone knows someone who would benefit they should tell them that we are open and to come into the shop.”

title: dundee united goalkeeper benjamin siegrist delighted to be working at christmas
story: His mates having been sending plenty reminders they are now on holiday while he’s working over the festive season but Dundee United goalie Benjamin Siegrist insists he’s the lucky one.Back home in Switzerland, players are now on holiday for Christmas and Siegrist has revealed a string of them haven’t been slow to let him know they’re enjoying putting their feet up.As he prepares for the festive programme that will see the Tangerines face Falkirk today and Alloa a week later, he insists he wouldn’t have it any other way.“I love it. I know what it is like over here from my time with Aston Villa,” he said.“In Switzerland last weekend it was the last game and now every one of my friends is on holiday. They are all sending me pictures so I block them on social media. I’m only kidding, for me it is just nice to be playing.“There is not one bit of jealously, I would rather be here and playing football over Christmas than be on holiday with them.“For me as a foreigner having been involved in the English game and now the Scottish game, I think it is beautul to be playing at this time of year.“You spend time with your family on Christmas Day but Boxing Day it is back into training to prepare for the next game and that’s what I like. We are playing today and then the th, there is no midweek game so it is perfect.“Listen, I live for playing football, I live and breathe football, so for me there is nothing better than having Christmas and then a game right away.”And, for Siegrist, the best Christmas presents he’ll get will be maximum points from Falkirk and Alloa.If United go about their business the way they did up at Inverness last weekend, he believes they will do exactly that.Although that Highland trip saw them have to fight back to earn a point, he believes the level of performance bodes well for what lies ahead in the league programme.“You never know what that point is worth until you finish the season, so that might be a very good one. However, the gaffer spoke about it to us during the week and the way we played compared to the week before at Morton was miles better.“That’s the way we want to play and we believe it gives us the best chance of winning every game or at least most of the games.“You are not going to walk through this league but we like to play with high tempo, pass the ball and cause problems for the opposition we can take advantage of. We just need to put it all together and get the three points.“We should be full of confidence the way we played last week because we know not every opposition can withstand the pressure we put on them.“It’s all about our performance, the way we go on the pitch and put into practice what we think we want to do.“The ability we have in the dressing-room, the characters we have, I think we have a really good team whether that’s in terms of spirit or ability.”After injury forced him off in the recent defeat against Ayr and forced him to miss the draw at Morton, Siegrist admits being recalled to the line-up last weekend was a boost for him.So far this term, one of his biggest battles has been to claim a starting place ahead of Matej Rakovan but that was an indication he’s now considered the first choice keeper by boss Robbie Neilson.“I’ve kind of over-extended when I was ing in the game against Ayr and it was a mixture between a knock and a muscle injury. It happens in football, you get injured sometimes and I was happy I was playing again as soon as I was back fit.”

title: everyone should be treated the same dundee boy kayden has a gift for giving
story: A Dundee primary school pupil has delved into his own pocket to prove he really does know the true meaning of Christmas.Nine-year-old Kayden Smith, from St Mary’s, who is a pupil at St Fergus RC Primary, has given up his own pocket money to buy food for people who are less well-off.He saved up £ a week and spent £ at the supermarket to help others during the festive period.Kayden said: “Every week for four weeks I went shopping with my grandma and bought food for other people who might be hungry. I decided that I should do this because I know that some people can’t afford to buy food and don’t have very much of their own.“I don’t like people having to feel like that so I thought I could use my pocket money to help them because I get plenty to eat.“I believe everyone should be treated the same and I thought this was the best way I could do something to help others less well-off then I am.”Kayden went to theof working out meal plans and decided to buy food that would cover breakfast, lunch and tea.“I bought things like porridge for breakfast, soup for lunch and tins of spaghetti bolognese and chicken curry for tea,” he said. “I got the curry because it’s my favourite and my mum makes the best chicken curry.”After he bought his groceries, Kayden would go to the food trolley in Asda Kirkton, where donations are collected and passed on to those who need them.He said: “I’m really happy to have been able to do it and I would do again another time.”Kayden’s gran Denise Smith, , said: “We are very proud of Kayden.“He thought this up all by himself and told me what he wanted to do and asked meI would help him. Every week, when I went round the supermarket with my trolley, Kayden would come along with his own trolley and select what he wanted to put in it.“He had carefully thought out meals and bought food for dferent times of the day. If one week he had money left over he saved it up for the next week so he had a little bit more to spend.”Denise said it wasn’t unusual for Kayden to want to help other people.She said: “If we go down the street and he sees someone sitting on the pavement he will often go up to them and give them some of his money.“That’s just how he is, and we are very proud of him. He’s told me he would like to do it again.”

title: five weeks of road closures ahead on key city route
story: Bus services and traffic are set to be heavily affected by a five-week-long phased closure of a busy city road.Claypotts Road will be closed in two stages during the -day maintenance scheme which will be undertaken by Tayside Contracts.The first phase will involve the street being closed off between Albert Road and Victoria Road.In the second phase of works, Claypotts Road will be closed between Victoria Road and Arbroath Road.Disruption is likely for public transport and motorists as the works will cut off a major link between the north and south of Broughty Ferry and could lead to a rise in traffic on neighbouring streets such as Seafield Road, Cedar Road and Forthill Road.Works will start on Monday January  and the contractor hopes to complete the programme by Sunday February .Ferry Liberal Democrat councillor Craig Duncan said those using the route should plan for the works.“The road does need a bit of TLC and I always say there’s never a good time to do these things – it’s a question of being patient,” he said.“The usual advice applies –you can, avoid the area and give yourself a bit of extra time when you’re leaving the house.”The road is used by Xplore Dundee and Stagecoach East Scotland. Services likely to be affected include the ,  A, , A C and the A C.Passengers are advised to check with the firms, or Traveline Scotland, ahead of their journey.Dundee City Council said ersions will be in place during the works, but is yet to publish details of its plans.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: “These roadworks are part of an ongoing roads maintenance programme across the city.“Arrangements for traffic will be in operation during the works and these will be signposted for motorists.”

title: mark ogren reveals why he chose to buy dundee united in 1500 word qa
story: New Dundee United chairman has revealed why he chose to buy Dundee United in a ,-word QA interview.The transcript of the telephone interview, published on Dundee United#s official website, reveals a historic connection. Here it is, in full, below.Congratulations on your purchase of Dundee United. I guess the obvious first question is why Dundee United My son Scott and I have been looking for investment in European football for some time. We looked at a lot of dferent options, and we looked at this particular club, the club#s history, the support of the fans, the previous success and rich history.The Irish history appealed because we are of Irish descent. We know the Club had financial issues and that makes it dficult for any Club to be successful.For the Club staff to work within that scenario where there is financial dficulty, you are hampered by that. Decisions are then based on where you are at rather than the best interests of the Club. We felt it was a sleeping giant and we could come in with our advisors and use our business experience to make a dference and get Dundee United back where it needs to be.How much did buying United cost you I will not answer that question directly but what I will say is I have seen some numbers thrown about out there and I wish we were buying it for as little as that! It comes to a combination of money paid to shareholders, money put in for the retirement of debt and a commitment to working capital to ensure funds going forward to do what we need to do to be successful.How long has buying a sporting opportunity in Europe been an interest or passion for you It has been there for several years. Scott#s passion for European football goes back much longer than that. It was his passion that rubbed off on me. His English team is Newcastle United, and we caught a match a few years back and had a lot of fun. In the last year, we really took the interest seriously.Are you looking to make money from this deal Yes. This isn#t a hobby for us, and we expect to make money long-term but, let me say, for that to happen we need to be competing in the Ladbrokes Premiership on a continual basis.How much do you know about Dundee United and Scottish football I know a ton. We spent a tremendous amount of time and money doing our due diligence. Legally, on the business side and on the performance side. We know a lot about Dundee United, and we have researched Scottish football, and we know where we are and where we want to go. We have an excellent plan to get where we want to go.Do you expect to own Dundee United for several years Yes. I expect to own the team long-term.What would you say to reassure Dundee United fans about the long-term future of the Club I guess what I would say is based on the due diligence conducted, spending a lot of time and money researching, we know what we are getting into. This isn#t just a passing fancy where we are going to get in and discover something that would create any issues for us. We are confident about what we are getting into and where we want to go. We would not invest in the Clubwe weren#t convinced about the long-term future of the Club.How does this purchase affect the structure of the Club Mike Martin has stepped down as Chairman, and I would like to recognise the work Mike has done during the process. He is a big fan of the Club, and he has steadied the ship since his appointment in March.As new owners, we are going to take it in a dferent direction. We plan to appoint a Managing Director who will be in charge of running the Club and he will be responsible for the aspects of the commercial and business side of the Club.We will also have a Sporting Director who will be responsible for all the performance aspects of the Club. He will work with Robbie Neilson efficiently and effectively from the Club’s standpoint.We will be making some announcements in the very near future regarding this.What type of Chairman would you describe yourself So I’ll be the Chairman and my son Scott will be the quasi-Vice Chairman. He will sit on the board with me. From a Club perspective, people can expect that I#ll be interested in all that is going on I will be very supportive of what#s going on and who is doing it I will be available whenever, but I will not be a micro-manager. We will have what we think are the right persons in the right positions to be a successful Club and I will absolutely expect results.From a fan perspective, I will be a low profile Chairman and fans will hear more from the Club leadership in the new structure than they will from me.Do you plan to work remotely Yes. I will work remotely and travel over as much as possible. Scott and I have talked about this. We will have board meetings that we will come over for, but we will try to tag-team and come across at separate times, so at least one of us is here as often as possible.How can you get a feel for the Clubyou aren#t over in Dundee With today#s technology it is almost asyou are over there but having the right people in the right positions is what matters. Jimmy Fyffe and David Dorward are still on the board, and we anticipate one or two other people to be on the board from the Dundee area. It is essential for the fans to know we will definitely have local representation and they will be in constant communications.There are American owners at Dundee FC, also within the city. So let me ask this directly. Do you have any plans to merge the clubs No. None whatsoever.Do you have any links at all with the owners of Dundee FC No, I have never met them, and quite frankly I do not even know who they are.Do you have any links to the previous owners of the Club including Stephen Thompson No, I have heard his name, but I have never met or had a discussion with Stephen Thompson. Obviously, I have met Mike Martin and Jimmy Fyffe.You have an interest in a Baseball team. What experience have you gained that will stand you in good stead for a football team based in Dundee I believe firmly, that a person needs to know their limitations. As Chairman and owner that is the situation. As far as performance of the squad aspect of the Club is concerned, I expect to be consulted with, I will be involved and interested in decisions, but in reality, I will defer the main decisions to those that know the game much better than I do. As I said previously, I#m not going to micro-manage. I expect to be much more involved in the business side.Have you spoken to the Head Coach and can you confirm that you see him leading the team forward So when I travelled across recently, I was introduced to Robbie, but quite frankly I don#t even think he knew who I was! I just happened to be a visitor who was introduced. That#s been the extent so far, but in answer to your question, I absolutely do believe he is the man to lead the team forward. He has made a positive impact since his arrival, and he has proven himself with Hearts before.Will he be given financial backing to help in the task of getting the Club back into the Ladbrokes Premiership I guess what I’d say is that it is not an open chequebook, but we absolutely intend to invest the necessary funds to get us into a position to get promoted. Equally important is when we get up we stay there.You will appreciate supporters will be curious and apprehensive about motives. How do you plan to communicate with fans of Dundee United Talk is cheap. What I would say to our supporters is judge us by our actions and, even more importantly judge us on our results. Obviously, due to the structure that I#ve discussed earlier, we will be implementing changes, and the fans will hear from the Club leadership rather than me.What targets do you intend to set for the team and the Club as a whole Let me answer it this way. We are looking at short-term and longer-term targets. The short-term objective is simple # promotion to the Premiership. We expect it is this year absolutely. We need to be United and have the one vision, # success # and get to the Premiership. The timing of the transaction is excellent. We have a transfer window shortly in January, and this will allow us to get with Robbie and figure out the team, andwe need to make some changes, we are ready and willing to do that.Longer-term, maybe three to five years, we need to be competing in the top six of the Premiership. We want to be competing in European competition and challenging in the cups. That#s our ultimate goal.

story: PREPARATIONS are under way in anticipation of work starting on an ambitious regeneration project next to the Caledonian Canal in Inverness ndash although planning permission is yet to be granted.Scottish Canals has a long-held aim to develop an outdoor hub and cafeacute on a derelict site off Carsegate Road, Merkinch.
